Toros said $30 million has been pledged of the program's $100 million cost. Despite the program's four-month delay, project director Dan Lindquist said the infested area has been restricted to northwestern Libya. Many of the shepherds targeted in the propaganda campaign are illiterate. But together with Libyan veterinarians they've helped contain the screwworm's spread by regularly checking their animals and quickly treating wounds. The infested zone starts about 25 miles east of the Tunisian border and runs past Tripoli along the Mediterranean coast for 190 miles. The zone reaches 30 to 60 miles inland.

DOC.HEAD: Thumbnail Sketches of Haiti's Presidential Candidates
With AM-Haiti, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are brief profiles of the main presidential candidates in Haiti's election: ---

JEAN-BERTRAND ARISTIDE - Roman Catholic priest with huge following among urban slum dwellers and rural peasants. Expelled from his ecclesiastical order in 1988 on grounds of fomenting revolution among the poor. Doctorate in theology, bachelor's degree in psychology. Studied abroad, fluent in many languages. Rose to prominence as critic of Duvalier family dictatorship and subsequent military regimes. Target of several assassination attempts, including one at his church in September 1988, when thugs massacred at least 12 of his parishioners and wounded 70 others. Born July 15, 1953. Nominated by National Front for Change and Democracy. ---

MARC BAZIN - Technocrat with international business ties. Advanced degrees in law and economics. World Bank official from 1968 to 1988, with leave in 1982 to serve as finance minister under Jean-Claude Duvalier. Fired after clamping down on corruption. Often called the ``American candidate,'' although U.S. Embassy denies any preference. Born March 6, 1932. Nominated by National Alliance for Democracy and Progress. ---

SYLVIO CLAUDE - Evangelical preacher. Vocal opponent of Duvalier family dictatorship, under which he was frequently imprisoned and was deported briefly to Colombia in 1979. Born Jan. 1, 1934. Nominated by Haitian Christian Democrat Party. ---

LOUIS DEJOIE JR. - Agronomist and wealthy landowner. Son of Sen. Louis Dejoie Sr., who lost 1957 election to Francois Duvalier. Was exiled in Mexico, then Cuba. Later settled in Puerto Rico, where he set up a construction firm. Born May 28, 1928. Nominated by National Industrial and Agricultural Party. ---

HUBERT DE RONCERAY - Sociologist; founding director, Haitian Social Science Research Center. Education minister and social affairs minister under Jean-Claude Duvalier. Forced into hiding in late 1980s for contesting Duvalierist presidency for life. Politically conservative. Arrested, tortured and briefly exiled in January 1990 roundup of prominent opponents of Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril's military regime. Born Aug. 20, 1932. Nominated by Mobilization for National Development Party. ---

THOMAS DESULME - Wealthy industrialist. As young senator in the 1940s, supported Francois Duvalier, but broke with dictator and went into exile in Jamaica. Invested in plastics industry and set up several factories in Jamaica before returning to Haiti in 1986. Born Jan. 1, 1913. Nominated by National Workers Party. ---

OTHER CANDIDATES - Vladimir Jeanty, Haitian Party of God, also known as Paradise Party; Volvick Remy Joseph, National Cooperation Movement; Francois Latortue, Democratic Movement for the Liberation of Haiti; Rene Theodore, Movement for National Reconstruction (Communist); Fritz Simon, independent.

DOC.HEAD: Kemp: Bush Likely to Maintain Minority-Only Scholarships
DOC.TEXT: Housing Secretary Jack Kemp predicted Sunday the Bush administration will find a way to preserve minority-only scholarships that are linked to students' financial needs. The White House and Justice Departments are reviewing a controversial opinion from the Education Department's top civil rights official that cast doubt on the legality of race-based scholarships. Kemp, speaking on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation,'' said, ``Like most Americans, I don't believe in race-based or religious-based quotas.'' But he added, ``I do believe in affirmative efforts by colleges to open up opportunity to minorities and low-income people.'' ``It would be a mistake for the federal government to shut off federal aid to a college ... because it's trying to promote opportunities for minorities based on need and minority status,'' he said. The dispute, which has upset many college administrators and civil rights groups, was triggered by an opinion circulated by Michael Williams, the assistant education secretary for civil rights, that federal law bars college scholarships predicated only on race. He warned colleges could lose their eligibility for federal aid if they gave such scholarships. But Kemp said Williams' interpretation of the law did not rule out scholarships based on race as well as financial need. ``I think that is what ultimately is going to be the case,'' said Kemp. President Bush said Friday that he had asked his staff for ``a quick readout on that so we can make a determination.'' Top White House officials, including Chief of Staff John H. Sununu, say they were caught by surprise by Williams' stance, which became public after he sent a letter to organizers of the football Fiesta Bowl in Tempe, Ariz., cautioning them about plans to provide $200,000 for minority scholarships at the University of Louisville and University of Alabama. Williams said the Fiesta Bowl itself could award the scholarships, but the two schools could not do it themselves. Williams said last week he had talked with lower level White House officials beforehand. A source said Williams even held up his letter to the Fiesta Bowl organizers for a week before sending it out without approval from anyone in the White House. Bush, a longtime backer of the United Negro College Fund, angered civil rights leaders by vetoing a job discrimination bill a few weeks before the November elections. Bush said the bill would have forced employers to resort to hiring quotas, which he opposes.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Secretary Sees Economic `Slowdown' Lasting Until Spring
DOC.TEXT: The nation's economy is undergoing a ``significant slowdown'' that is likely to persist through early 1991 before turning around later next year, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said Sunday. ``I have been a little slow to declare national recession day,'' Brady said. Many private economists, however, have pronounced the economy in recession, with layoffs rising and banks in trouble, and with the retail sales, housing and car markets down. A recession is defined as a contraction of six months or more in the gross national product. ``I think it is quite clear that economic activity in the fourth quarter of this year has slowed down,'' Brady said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' program. ``How much we don't know yet, but it's a significant slowdown.'' Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan told a House committee last month said that oil-price problems resulting from the military standoff in the Persian Gulf had helped push the economy into a ``meaningful downturn.'' Brady, asked why he was reluctant to use the word recession, said Sunday he did not have all the figures for th quarter. ``Let's watch and see,'' Brady said. ``Maybe it will be. I don't think it's the end of the world even it we have a recession. We'll pull back out of it again. No big deal.'' While optimistic about the U.S. economy in the long-term, Brady said there was ``no point being unrealistic'' about the sluggish economy. ``I expect that that will continue into the first quarter of this year.'' ``We expect that during 1991 that it (the economy) will turn around and we'll be back on the growth path, jobs, investment, during that year,'' he added. Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, also was confident about the future. ``Right now the best guess is the economy will be reviving sometime next year, whether we will have a recession that lasts several quarters - it should be mild and brief - or we narrowly skirt it,'' he said on ABC-TV's ``This Week With David Brinkley.'' Bush administration officials blamed the Persian Gulf crisis for aggravating the downturn by jacking up oil prices and sapping consumer confidence. ``I am obviously concerned about events in the Persian Gulf,'' Boskin said. ``I think they have heavily influenced the short-term impact on the economy.'' After Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, oil prices rose sharply because of the cut in supplies caused by economic sanctions against Iraq. ``The economy is already feeling the effects of the situation in the gulf,'' Brady said. ``I myself, every American says, `Well, I'm just going to wait and see a little bit.' If I was going to buy a new car, I'll slow down on it.'' Moreover, Boskin said the government might have to borrow money to pay for Operation Desert Shield. Congressional Democrats say the cost of keeping as many as 400,000 U.S. troops in the gulf could add up to $36.8 billion in fiscal year 1991. The Bush administration intends to ask Congress for $20 billion early next year, House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said Saturday. President Bush, meantime, is looking at a range of options to stimulate the economy, including ways to lower the cost of capital and generate jobs, Boskin said. Brady and Boskin said they both favored having the Federal Reserve drop interest rates to boost the economy. ``I think there is ample room for a further reduction in interest rates,'' Brady said. Brady drew a distinction between the crisis in the banking industry and the situation with failed savings and loan institutions, which is expected to cost taxpayers up to $100 billion this year. ``Banks are not as healthy as we would like them,'' he said. ``The banks have $200 billion worth of capital, with another $60 billion in reserves,'' he said. ``When the S&L industry got into trouble, it had $10 billion.'' L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said on the NBC program that bank losses are expected to total $4 billion this year and possibly $5 billion next year. The FDIC is working on a plan to have bankers pay to recapitalize the government insurance fund, he said. Meantime, a House Banking subcommittee is due to release a report Monday saying that if the country experiences a severe recession, bank losses could total $63 billion. And even a mild downturn in the economy could leave the FDIC fund short of cash.

DOC.HEAD: Effort Begins To Develop Better School Tests
DOC.TEXT: Two leading education research centers announced Sunday they have received grants to devise better ways to measure the thinking skills students will need to become successful adults. The University of Pittsburgh's Learning Research and Development Center will receive $1.15 million from the Pew Charitable Trusts of Philadelphia. For a related study, the National Center on Education and the Economy in Rochester, N.Y., will get $1.3 million from the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation of Chicago. The Pittsburgh group will deal primarily with technical aspects of the study, while the Rochester center will focus on broader policy questions, Betsy Brown Ruzzi, senior associate of the Rochester group's Washington office, said in a telephone interview. The grants will fund the first 18 months of what could become a decade-long effort to replace the common multiple choice tests with a new testing method that measures how well students perform in real-life situations, officials of both centers said. Growing numbers of educators and business leaders have complained that standardized tests give misleadingly positive signals about how well-prepared U.S. youngsters are for the complex problems they will face as workers and citizens. Paul H. O'Neill, chief executive officer of ALCOA and chairman of the President's Education Policy Advisory Committee, called the grants ``very good news.'' ``Improved assessment will help us to understand local, national and internationl comparisons and point the way to necessary changes in our education process,'' he said. The first glimpse of the proposed assessments appeared in the Rochester center's landmark report last June, ``America's Choice: High Skills or Low Wages,'' which decried U.S. students' lack of preparation for the level of thinking and organization needed to thrive in the workplace. According to the two research centers, the proposed new testing methods would likely include: - ``performance examinations,'' in which students would demonstrate their mastery of specific skills to panels of examiners - much as an Olympic figure skater tries to impress a panel of judges, said Ruzzi. - ``projects'' in which students show their ability to use problem-solving skills over time, often in cooperation with other students. - ``portfolios,'' consisting of the best work done by students in a variety of areas over time. ``The goal of the new assessment system is not simply to create better exams. The nation would be ill-served if high standards were put in place, but few students were able or motivated to reach them,'' said Marc Tucker, president of the Rochester-based center. Politicians and educators have been grappling for the past year to devise better ways to measure their progress toward an ambitious set of goals to improve education that was agreed upon last February by President Bush and the nation's 50 governors. A 14-member National Education Goals Panel led by Colorado Gov. Roy Romer is scheduled to hold its latest meeting in Washington on Wednesday. Romer, in a statement accompanying Sunday's announcement, applauded the Pittsburgh-Rochester project as ``a critical and much-needed contribution to ongoing efforts to restructure schools.'' The two research centers said they planned over the next three months to assemble a group of school districts and states that would help develop and test the assessment project. The project's leaders said they hope that initial group will also form the foundation of a national system that could demonstrate whether the new brand of assessment is better than multiple-choice testing.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 10 Killed in Hindu-Moslem Violence
DOC.TEXT: Police fired on mobs of Hindus and Moslems to try to stop rioting not far from the Taj Mahal, and news reports said six people were killed and 12 wounded. The Press Trust of India reported that two bodies, believed to be of victims of Hindu-Moslem violence, also were recovered Sunday in Agra, the site of the famed monument. The riots occurred within three miles of the Taj Mahal, one of India's leading tourist attractions. Two people also were killed Sunday in sectarian violence in Jaipur, the capital of the desert state of Rajasthan, news reports said. Hindu-Moslem clashes have left at least 296 people dead across central and western India in the past 10 days. They started when Hindu fundamentalists revived a campaign to build a temple on the site now occupied by a mosque in the Hindu holy town of Ayodhya. In Agra, PTI reported at least 20 cases of rioting, arson and looting. Police repeatedly urged the rioting mobs to stop before firing, the news agency said. Sectarian violence has flared intermittently since India achieved independence from Britain in 1947. Moslems account for 12 percent of India's 880 million people and Hindus comprise 82 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Oldest Operating Spacecraft Marks 25 years in Orbit
DOC.TEXT: The oldest operating spacecraft marked a quarter-century in orbit Sunday. Pioneer 6, a 140-pound cylindrical probe about a yard long and a yard wide, was rocketed into space atop a Delta rocket 25 years ago. But retired managers of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration Pioneer program won't celebrate the anniversary until Monday when they plan to tune the probe's signal from the Ames Research Center in Mountain View. The probe was designed to relay to Earth the first detailed measurements from the other side of the sun of magnetic fields, cosmic rays and solar wind particles. The journey was expected to last six months. But the signal has never stopped, despite the failure of three of six instruments and the flagging efficiency of the solar cells. Engineers at NASA and TRW Inc. of Redondo Beach, which built the probe, estimate that the probe has traveled 15.4 billion miles during 29 orbits around the sun.

DOC.HEAD: British Diplomats, Last to Leave Kuwait, Arrive in Baghdad
DOC.TEXT: Britain's ambassador to Kuwait and the British consul arrived in Baghdad on Sunday, the last two Western diplomats to leave the Iraqi-occupied emirate, British diplomats said. Ambassador Michael Weston and Consul Larry Banks left the embassy ``open but unmanned, and the Union Jack was still flying on the premises,'' one diplomat said. They flew to Baghdad, the Iraqi capital, on a regularly scheduled Iraqi Airways flight. The British government had said it would remove the remaining staff members once all Britons who wanted to leave the country were gone. About 500 Britons were evacuated in a major airlift last week following Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's decision to allow all foreigners to leave Iraq and Kuwait. About 40 Britons, mostly women married to Kuwaitis, stayed behind. After its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Iraq ordered foreign embassies to close by Aug. 24. About two dozen mostly Western embassies defied the orders but closed one by one in face of an Iraqi seige that cut utilities and most of the food supplies. The United States and Britain continued to keep their embassies open. American Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and the other four U.S. diplomats in Kuwait left last week, saying all Americans who wished to leave had done so. Weston and Banks were expected to leave for London on Monday via Amman, Jordan, on a scheduled Iraqi Airways flight, according to Britain's embassy in Baghdad.

DOC.HEAD: Government Praises EC Action, Black Groups Deplore It
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Government and business leaders praised the European Community's decision to ease sanctions on South Africa, but black opposition groups on Sunday criticized the move. The EC said on Saturday it was lifting a voluntary ban on new investment in South Africa. It left intact embargoes on the imports of iron, steel and gold coins, and on arms exports. It was the first major sanction to be lifted against South Africa since Western countries began imposing punitive measures in the mid-1980s. Thabo Mbeki, head of the African National Congress' foreign affairs department, said Sunday his movement ``is not going to stand still on this matter.'' Mbeki said the ANC would be in contact with the United States and others in a bid to keep present sanctions in place. The EC, in an announcement Saturday at its summit in Rome, said it would further ease sanctions when South Africa eliminates remaining apartheid laws that segregate citizens by race and keep the white minority in power. Foreign Affairs Minister Pik Botha hailed the EC's move, calling it ``positive recognition for President F.W. de Klerk's courageous steps.'' ``This also means that the state president's initiatives have started a dramatic reversal in South Africa's foreign relations,'' he said Saturday. ``This will be to the advantage of all the people of South Africa.'' Anglo American, South Africa's largest corporation that dominates the gold-mining industry, said in a statement Saturday it expected the United States to take similar action next year. The company called the EC move a major step toward normalizing relations between South Africa and the international community. The European decision came as the African National Congress, the largest black opposition group, voted at a conference Saturday to maintain its support for sanctions as a means of pressure on the government to eliminate apartheid. Other opposition groups also expressed bitterness. ``The EC decision was to be expected because white people support other white people,'' Itumeleng Mosala of the radical Azanian People's Organization said Saturday. ``This will be a lesson to black liberationmovements to know that in the struggle, they are on their own.'' In lifting the ban on new investment, the EC followed the lead of Britain, which announced earlier this year it would unilaterally end a ban on new investment to indicate support for de Klerk's reforms. Since Britain's move, there has been no announcement of major British investment in South Africa. There was no way to effectively gauge the immediate impact of the EC action. Symbolically, though, it showed growing international acceptance that the demise of apartheid was inevitable and raised the prospect of other sanctions being lifted. South Africa's economy, potentially the strongest in southern Africa, has been in recession for a year, due in part to the isolation caused by sanctions. For example, more than half the 300 U.S. companies doing business in South Africa have pulled out since sanctions took effect in 1986. Many sold out to local managers but continue to hold licensing agreements in South Africa. If the United States also lifts a ban on new investment, such companies could buy back their facilities and resume production. But foreign investors have adopted a cautious attitude toward South Africa because of chronic violence among black factions, the changing political climate and the recession.

DOC.HEAD: Aftershocks Hit Sicily, Prompting Panic
DOC.TEXT: A strong aftershock jolted eastern Sicily on Sunday, sending thousands of people rushing into the streets three days after a more powerful earthquake killed 17 people. The earthquake that rocked the island Thursday partially destroyed the town of Carlentini. Sunday's quake measured 3.9 on the Richter scale, according to the Ettore Majorana scientific center in the town of Erice. A temblor of 3.5 can cause slight damage, while one of 4 can provoke moderate damage. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. The epicenter Sunday was about 30 miles southeast of Sicily in the Gulf of Noto. It was followed by a series of more minor shocks. In Carlentini, chunks of plaster toppled from buildings as the aftershock hit. Many inhabitants in the town of 10,000 ran into the main square. Residents of Syracuse also rushed into piazzas and open areas. In a jail in the city, inmates launched a protest, demanding to be transferred to a more secure location. Police surrounded the building and fired in the air to quiet the prisoners.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio's Mount Vernon Helps Counterpart in Washington State
DOC.TEXT: Residents of this city share with residents of Mount Vernon, Wash., a hometown name as well as memories of devastating floods and the kindness of faraway strangers. Mount Vernon, Ohio, Mayor Ernie Farmer said his city's residents sent more than $5,000 to the Washington city of the same name this week to aid the victims of November's floods. The flooding in Mount Vernon, Wash., left more than 150 people homeless and caused nearly $20 million damage. When flooding struck the Ohio community in 1959, residents of Mount Vernon, Wash., sent $1,000 and a planeload of food and clothing. Farmer said his community's 1,300 residents never forgot the favor. ``Good deeds last forever,'' he said. Mayor Ray Reep of the Mount Vernon, Washington, which has about 18,000 residents, said the money was welcome. ``It shows there's still a true spirit in this country,'' Reep said. ``I wish we'd see it more often.'' Both mayors said the two communities share a bond, even though their only contact was 31 years ago. ``It's kind of like we adopted each other,'' Reep said.

DOC.HEAD: Daily News Publisher Calls for Appointment of `Super Mediator'
DOC.TEXT: The publisher of the strikebound Daily News Sunday called for the appointment of a federal mediator to force both sides toward a settlement. ``What we are in favor of is a very high-powered, supermediator ... to come in and knock everybody's heads together,'' Publisher James Hoge said on a local television news program. On the same show, Newspaper Guild President Barry Lipton said: ``We're willing to consider anything that will bring about a fair and equitable settlement.'' Hoge and Lipton both rejected binding arbitration. Both sides met separately in Washington last week with the head of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, Bernard DeLury. No progress was made because the nine striking unions want to bargain as a group and the company wants to bargain with them individually. Both sides agreed to be recalled, but DeLury said he would wait a few days before recalling them. The News has published every day since the strike began Oct. 25, but it has lost advertisers and about half of its circulation, which was 1.09 million before the strike.

DOC.HEAD: Caretaker Government Frees Some Prisoners
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to delete reference to Independence Day, which is celebrated later, moves up reference to event being commemorated Sunday. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Bangladesh's caretaker government marked the anniversary of independence from Pakistan by freeing 167 prisoners Sunday, the second group released since Hussain Muhammad Ershad was ousted as president. Ershad was ousted earlier this month and then arrested last week. No charges have yet been filed, but he is likely to be tried for corruption. The Home Ministry said 124 people awaiting trial and 43 who were convicted of criminal offenses were freed on Sunday. It did not identify them. Prisoner releases on holidays are common in Bangladesh. Dec. 16 marks the day in 1971 that Bangladesh broke away from Pakistan with the backing of Indian troops. Formal independence is celebrated in March. Political prisoners detained by Ershad's government were released after he was forced from office on Dec. 6. Ershad, a 60-year-old former army general, stepped down after seven weeks of often violent protests and strikes. He handed over power to Shahabuddin Ahmed, the Supreme Court chief justice. Elections are scheduled for March 2 to set up a democratic government after 19 years of political turbulence marked by coups and assasinations. Of the nine heads of state that Bangladesh has had so far, two - including the first president - have been assassinated in military coups. Ershad, who seized power in a bloodless coup in 1982, had nine months left in his five-year term when he was forced out. In 1986, he was elected president in balloting that foreign observers and the opposition said was rigged. He conducted two parliamentary elections, but allegations of fraud were made in both. The last election, in 1988, was boycotted by the two major opposition parties.

DOC.HEAD: Moldavians Rally on Eve of Parliament Session
LaserPhoto MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of thousands of Moldavians on Sunday demanded independence from the Kremlin, demonstrating on the eve of a parliament session to consider President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's new Union Treaty. Gorbachev will preside over the opening of the fourth session of the 2,250-member Congress of Peoples' Deputies, which also will consider a proposal to strengthen Gorbachev's control over the fragmenting union. Demonstrators on Sunday packed the center of Kishinev, capital of the southwestern republic of Moldavia, in a self-declared ``Grand National Assembly.'' They demanded the Kremlin acknowledge Moldavian sovereignty and called for changing Moldavia's name to the ``Republic of Moldavia,'' dropping the words ``Soviet socialist.'' Marchers carried banners that said ``Down With The Russian Empire,'' and ``Long Live Greater Romania.'' Moldavia, formerly called Bessarabia by Romanians, has strong ethnic ties to that neighboring country. More than 65 percent of Moldavia's 4.3 million people speak a language identical to Romanian, except that it uses Cyrillic characters. Romanian President Ion Iliescu has called for a unification of Romania and Bessarabia into a ``Greater Romania.'' Soviet television showed hundreds of thousands of people crowded into a central square for the rally organized by the nationalist Moldavian Popular Front. Some reports put the crowd size at 800,000, but the figure could not be verified. The republic, like nearly all the other 15 republics, has declared autonomy over central Kremlin control. Several smaller ethnic groups and regions within republics have sided with the Kremlin, most fearing discrimination by the republics' majority nationalities. In Estonia, about 3,000 demonstrators, mostly ethnic Russians, rallied Sunday in support of Gorbachev and against the independence-minded Estonian leadership, according to the independent Estonian News Agency. The 21-month-old national parliament is expected to approve a draft of the Union Treaty, the new charter proposed by Gorbachev to redefine the relationship between the central government and the republics. Under the proposed treaty, the national government would retain control over defense and national security, as well as energy, transportation and other key industries. Republics would gain some control over economic decisions and their participation theoretically would be voluntary. Gorbachev has said quick adoption of the treaty is necessary for staving off further deterioration of the national economy. The Baltic republics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, plus Moldavia, have refused to join the talks. The Congress also is expected to approve the streamlining of the executive branch of government that Gorbachev proposed last month to break the paralysis of power that is hampering his reforms. Under his plan, the Council of Ministers, or Cabinet, headed by Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov would be replaced by several bodies under direct presidential control. The Congress session likely will include tumultuous debate, heightened by a newly assertive hard-line wing and a larger but more disorganized liberal side. The liberal Inter-regional Group of Deputies has been unable to agree on a stance toward the Union Treaty, while reformist Moscow Mayor Gavriil Popov urged in a newspaper interview Sunday that the Congress be dissolved and replaced by a new parliament that would elect a new president. In recent weeks, Gorbachev has appeared to be trying to appease the hard-liners. He has replaced the moderate interior minister with a KGB general expected to crack down on political uprisings. He has also ordered harsher KGB and army action. KGB chairman Vladimir Kryuchkov last week pledged a crackdown on radicals who he said were trying to gain power by sabotaging food supplies during the nation's economic crisis. Gorbachev also has ordered the KGB, the army and Interior Ministry to stop workers in the state distribution system from stealing food and selling it on the black market. Such pilfering is one key factor contributing to the nation's food crisis, which has seen supplies of goods dwindle at state stores.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Guerrillas Retaliate for Army Raid
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas have launched a series of attacks nationwide in retaliation for the army's raid on their headquarters, officials said Sunday. At least eight people have been reported killed. Troops overcame the last pocket of resistance at the guerrillas' headquarters in a battle Saturday, according to an official statement published in local newspapers. The mountaintop stronghold is 90 miles south of Bogota, the Colombian capital. An official statement said the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia responded by carrying out a dynamite attack in the city of Medellin late Saturday. The explosion, targeting a police patrol, killed a civilian and wounded a police officer, according to the official statement. Officials suspect the guerrilla movement was also behind a similar attack in Medellin on Dec. 10 in which seven police officers were killed. Earlier Saturday, 10 rebels burned a small commercial aircraft after attacking the airport of Villa Garzon, a town about 300 miles south of Bogota. The guerrillas forced the 19 people aboard to evacuate the plane before setting it on fire, according to a statement by Aires Airlines, the aircraft's Colombian owner. In addition, army and police statements accused the guerrilla movement and an allied rebel group of dynamiting an electrical tower in northern Colombia on Saturday, attacking a military base in the north on Friday, and burning a helicopter during an attack Wednesday on an oil well in southern Colombia. No victims were reported in those attacks. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, with an estimated 5,000 combatants, is the oldest and largest of Colombia's leftist guerrilla groups. Fighting between government troops and the guerrilla movement has left more than 50 people dead since Dec. 9, when the army began its assault on the rebel headquarters. In other violence, seven people were killed Saturday in a massacre near the town of Bolivar, 150 miles south of Bogota. Police say they have not been able to identify the killers, who fled the scene.

DOC.HEAD: South Korean President Leaves Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: South Korean President Roh Tae-woo left the Soviet Union Sunday after ending a 30-year diplomatic chill and opening new communications in efforts to settle hostilities on the Korean Peninsula, Tass reported. ``I and President Mikhail Gorbachev have announced to the entire world that we will pay maximum effort to establish peace on the Korean Peninsula and the Asian-Pacific region,'' Roh said at a luncheon in Leningrad before departing for home. Roh, the first leader in the history of his country to visit the Soviet Union, met in the Kremlin on Friday with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the two leaders signed a declaration of ``trust and cooperation.'' The summit capped a reversal of Cold War relations. They reached a low point in 1983 when a Soviet jet shot down Korean Air Lines Flight 007 after it had strayed into Soviet air space. All 269 people aboard the civilian jetliner were killed. Roh said Friday that the new relationship with the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War in the Pacific region could give impetus to the drive to reunite his Western-allied country with Communist North Korea. Roh said Gorbachev urged him to have patience on the question of reunification and ``develop an atmosphere of mutual trust, and in that climate, it will be more propitious for specific ways for the unification of Korea.'' During the talks, the two sides also signed agreements on trade and scientific and technological cooperation, Roh said. The two countries formally re-established diplomatic relations Sept. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Recall Romanian Revolution, Demand Government Resign
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Romanians rallied Sunday in Timisoara, where the country's popular revolution was born, in an emotional first anniversary celebration of the death of Communism. They also demanded the resignation of the current government, which was democratically elected but is dominated by former Communists. About 15,000 people gathered as snow fell in Opera Square, the site of last year's violent protests that led to the ouster and execution of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. ``Twelve months of lies!'' the demonstrators chanted, some waving Romanian tri-color flags with holes cut in the middle to resemble those of the revolution with the Communist emblem excised. In the capital, Bucharest, several hundred anti-government demonstrators occupied central University Square in the early evening. They shouted demands for the resignation of Iliescu and the government and blocked traffic before being dispersed by about 300 club-wielding police. No arrests or injuries were reported. In a national television address Sunday night, President Ion Iliescu appealed for calm and tried to quell opposition fears. ``To negate the results of the elections only six months after they were held and impose something else in the name of a dissatisfied minority... would only amplify our difficulties,'' he said. The post-Ceausescu provisional government led by Iliescu's National Salvation Front capitalized on the elation following the revolution to overwhelmingly win democratic elections May 20. Since then, however, economic hardship and the growing suspicion that senior Front officials who previously served Ceausescu have not broken with Communism has turned many people against the Front. Unrest has grown over the last month in Timisoara, Bucharest and elsewhere. Demonstrators have demanded the resignation of Iliescu, Premier Petre Roman and other senior officials. Those demands were voiced again Sunday. But the rallies in both Timisoara and Bucharest were smaller than expected, perhaps because of recent government pledges to postpone price hikes on food and other goods from January to June. In Timisoara, opposition politicians, student activists and labor leaders speaking from the balcony of the city opera house all said the government had betrayed the revolution. ``Down with Iliescu; down with the Communist government!'' they chanted. ``Iliescu at Christmas, you're the best pig to slaughter!'' ``Down with the Securitate!'' the crowd roared, alluding to widespread perceptions that the government continues to tolerate Ceausescu's feared secret police. ``Hands soaked in blood!'' Passers-by applauded. Several old men and women, dressed in black and clutching pictures of sons and daughters killed by army and Securitate bullets last year, wept and crossed themselves as the marchers knelt and intoned prayers. ``The last chance - another revolution!'' the crowd chanted. Earlier this month, the government postponed price increases for basic foodstuffs and services from January to June. The move appeared to take some of the fight out of Bucharest workers and students, who backed away from planned strikes aimed at bringing down the leadership. But in Timisoara, a city of 283,000 about 300 miles northwest of the capital, anti-government activism continued. Eleven local factories employing about 50,000 people have been on strike since Dec. 9. Student representatives said about 22,000 university students had been boycotting classes since Dec. 9 and would continue the boycott after the end of Christmas break, Jan. 6, unless national leaders resign. About 100,000 students and hundreds of professors are striking nationwide. Timisoara's central role in the revolution accounts for some of its radicalism. The uprising began last Dec. 16 outside the local yellow-brick church of Laszlo Toekes, the ethnic Hungarian pastor whose fervent criticism of Ceausescu prompted an order by the dictator to forcibly resettle him. Police broke into the church, beat Toekes and took him away. Parishioners and others who had gathered outside marched to the Communist Party headquarters, where they broke windows and set fires. Demonstrations spread across Romania and there were vicious street battles between citizens and the heavily armed secret police. The army sided with the citizens, however, and Ceausescu fled Bucharest on Dec. 22. He was captured a day later and executed on Christmas Day. Toekes now is a bishop of his Reformed Church of Protestants and lives in Oradea, 40 miles northeast of Timisoara. He returned to his former church Sunday to hold a commemorative service.

DOC.HEAD: Many Foreign Airlines Unsafe, Newspaper Reports
DOC.TEXT: A double standard, encouraged by international agreements, exists for foreign airlines operating in the United States, endangering passengers, crews and people on the ground, a newspaper reported Sunday. The Federal Aviation Administration never verifies the qualifications of pilots for foreign airlines and fails to inspect foreign-owned airline equipment unless the other government requests it, according to New York Newsday. In its five-month investigation, Newsday ran a computer analysis of some 700 accidents worldwide; conducted scores of interviews; and reviewed thousands of documents, some obtained through the Freedom of Information Act. Newsday said pilots for some foreign carriers don't get training in such basic elements as supervising crews and using devices that warn of collision with high terrain. In the last 20 years, almost 21,000 people have been killed on foreign airlines. Those carriers make about half of all flights but account for 80 percent of the deaths worldwide, Newsday said. This year, the gap was even wider: Almost 500 people died on foreign planes while only 37 were killed on U.S. carriers. The statistics exclude accidents caused by sabotage or terrorism. FAA spokesman Fred Ferrar in Washington said Sunday he hadn't seen the story and didn't want to comment. Bill Spohrer, who runs Challenge Air Cargo in Miami, told how regulators from Central American countries inspected the airlines he used to run in Nicaragua and Honduras: ``The inspector would come up and we'd put him up at the hotel. He'd bring his wife or girlfriend, and they'd go shopping. On the last day before he had to leave, he'd come by and say, `OK, what do I have to sign?''' Richard Haberly, president of a small Miami-based cargo airline, scuttled plans to lease a jet he needed when the FAA said it would require $300,000 in modifications to meet U.S. safety standards. A month later, he saw it land in Miami under the colors of a foreign carrier. ``It's just awful we allow them to come to the U.S. with barely any regulation at all,'' said Robert Lochner, a former FAA inspector who was supposed to oversee 60 foreign carriers by himself. Newsday said most carriers from wealthier nations had above-average safety records, but many from developing countries and Eastern Europe were among the most dangerous. Although the FAA has authority to inspect foreign carriers, under international practice, the United States usually just accepts a foreign country's word about crew qualifications and planes' worthiness. Anthony Broderick, the FAA's associate administrator for regulation in Washington, D.C., told Newsday that the FAA doesn't examine foreign carriers closely because the current system works. ``Tragic accidents, despite the best efforts of the best agencies in the world, sometimes happen,'' said Broderick. ``But there are very few international accidents in the United States or around the world. These international agreements have proven the test of time and work well.'' Newsday said the National Transportation Safety Board plans to rule early next year on the probable cause of the Avianca crash last January on Long Island that killed 73 people. The newspaper reported that the NTSB is expected to recommend that the FAA beef up its rules for foreign carriers and crews because of problems uncovered in that accident.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Defense Chief Promises More Deportations
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Moshe Arens on Sunday defended the decision to deport four Moslem fundamentalists following the stabbing deaths of three Israelis. He said the explusions ``will not be the last.'' The deportation order, criticized by the U.S. State Department and some Israeli officials, was appealed by Arab lawyers Sunday as authorities placed the occupied Gaza Strip under curfew and planned to bar some Arabs from entering Jerusalem. Israel reinstituted its controversial deportation policy after a 16-month break. Recently, public anxiety about Arab attacks has risen, and right-wing politicians have urged a harsh crackdown. Israel wants to show Arabs linked to murders that it ``will cause immediate deportation of people he knows, whom he works with and who incite him to violence,'' Arens said on army radio. ``I believe that the deportation ... will not be the last, and we will not hesitate to use this tool in the future in the ame instances where it will be effective,'' Arens said. Health Minister Ehud Olmert indicated Israel wants to expel more Arabs but is sensitive to U.S. criticism. The Yedioth Ahronoth newspaper said Arens wanted to deport 14 Palestinians, but that Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir approved only four. The deportations were ordered Saturday, a day after three Jews were stabbed to death in a factory in the Tel Aviv suburb of Jaffa. Hamas, or Zeal, an underground Moslem fundamentalist group, claimed responsibility. Hamas published a leaflet Sunday praising the killings and calling for a week of escalated attacks on Israelis, Israel radio and television reported. The four ordered deported were from the Gaza Strip and were known Hamas activists who helped organize acts of violence. The army said about 600 Arabs were arrested in a weekend sweep on Hamas activists. However, Israeli authorities have not said if the people they ordered out are suspected of involvement in the murders. Arab lawyers in Gaza appealed the deportation orders to a military board Sunday. The appeal is expected to be considered Monday, Israeli media said. Curfews confined about 320,000 Gaza residents to their homes, and a naval blockade stopped fishermen from launching their boats Sunday. In Tel Aviv, police reportedly rounded up some Palestinian workers and bused them back to Gaza after detaining them overnight. Police spokesman Ron Yishayahu said those without permits to stay in Israel overnight were being sent home. Yishayahu did not say how many Palestinians were being taken back to Gaza. About 110,000 Arabs from the occupied territories work in Israel. Israel television said police also planned to bar Arabs from the occupied West Bank and Gaza from entering Jerusalem on Monday. Authorities fear violence at the Temple Mount, where Jewish extremists have threatened to demonstrate for the Hanukkah holiday. At least 17 Palestinians were killed by Israeli police gunfire in October during Arab riots at Temple Mount. There was new criticism Sunday of the deportation order. The U.S. State Department denounced it as a violation of human rights protection provided by the Geneva Convention. ``We hope the Israeli government will come up with some other way of dealing with the problem,'' U.S. Sen. Daniel K. Inouye, D-Hawaii, told reporters in Jerusalem. Interior Minister Aryeh Deri of Israel was also critical. ``They should have been put on trial and then deported,'' Deri, of the ultra-Orthodox Torah Guardians Party, told the national Itim news agency. Shimon Peres, leader of the left-of-center Labor Party, said, ``I suggest we stop competing for who can climb higher on the ladder of violence and see how we can lower the escalation rather than raise it ... walls, sticks and deportations won't solve the problem.'' Sixty Arabs have been expelled since the Palestinian uprising began in December 1987. The last to be deported were five Palestinians in August 1989. The Palestine Liberation Organization on Sunday denounced the deportation order as ``a violation of international law,'' according to a statement received in Nicosia, Cyprus.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Hits Vermont Hard; Colorado Braces for Avalanches
DOC.TEXT: Winter weather moved into the Northeast on Sunday, dumping more than a foot of snow in some parts of Vermont, and snow or rain pelted much of the remainder of the nation while Colorado prepared for more snow and avalanches. In Vermont, up to 14 inches of snow fell by early afternoon at Waitsfield, 12 inches at St. Johnsbury and Middlebury, and 10 inches at Williamstown. Meanwhile, rain extended across southern Maine and New Hampshire, and rain changed to snow across Vermont into northeast New York state. Snow also reached across western New York state into the mountains of north-central Pennsylvania and higher elevations of south-central New York state. Other snowstruck areas: parts of Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, Utah, Wyoming, Idaho and Montana. Colorado braced for a second blast of snow Sunday night as a storm headed into the state. Snow and avalanche warnings were issued. A storm that swept through southern Colorado dumped 4 inches at Alamosa, and up to 8 inches of new snow in the mountains overnight Saturday. More than 50 avalanches have been reported since Friday, according to Colorado Avalanche Information Center officials. Some were induced by professional snow workers, but many occurred naturally. Rain extended across western Pennsylvania, eastern Ohio and northwestern West Virginia. Parts of Alabama, Tennessee, Mississippi, Arkansas, Louisiana, Texas, Oklahoma, Missouri and Kansas also got hit with some rain. Rain fell in western Washington state, with rain changing to snow in the mountains. The nation's low Sunday morning was 19 degrees below zero at Jackson, Wyo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 11 degrees at Jackson to 83 at Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Blast Rips Through EC Offices In Athens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with police official saying anti-tank missiles used, ADDS previous attack on EC offices; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Two anti-tank missiles crashed into the European Community's offices in downtown Athens late Sunday, causing damages and slightly injuring two passers-by, police said. There was no immediate claim of responsibility. However, leftist guerrillas claimed responsibility for a bombing at the EC bureau's offices a year ago. Regional police chief Simeon Papadogiorgos said the explosion was caused by two anti-tank missiles. A spokesman at police headquarters did not say whether there were employees in the office at the time nor whether the usual police guards were at the building's entrance. Two women at a nearby bus stop were slightly injured by flying glass, the spokesman said on condition of anonymity. The EC offices were damaged in December 1989 by a bomb planted by the Revolutionary Popular Struggle, a leftist group that has staged a bombing campaign since the mid-1970s. No one was injured in that attack. In addition, Greece's most notorious urban guerrilla group, November 17, has used anti-tank missiles in the past in an attack on a U.S.-based multinational corporation and on a Greek shipowner. The leftist group has killed 14 people since 1975. November 17 is opposed to Greece's EC and NATO membership and to the U.S. military presence in Greece. The group has killed 14 people since 1975, without any of its members being arrested. Parliament is due to vote on a new anti-terrorism law Monday to give police wider powers to investigate suspects and bar news media from publicizing statements by terrorist groups.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Soldiers, Guerrillas Clash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 10 grafs pvs, `Yater is ...,' to ADD later Israeli attacks. Pickup 11th graf pvs, `The Israeli ....' MINOR EDITING thruout
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli army patrol clashed Sunday with a Palestinian guerrilla squad in southern Lebanon. Police said three guerrillas were killed and two Israeli soldiers wounded. The Israeli military confirmed that two soldiers were wounded, but said one guerrilla was killed and one wounded. The early-morning shootout was near the village of Yater, 11 miles south of Tyre, Lebanon's southernmost port on the Mediterranean, police reported. The village is on the edge of Israel's self-designated ``security zone'' it uses as a buffer against cross-border guerrilla forays. The Israeli military said infantry troops encountered the guerrilla squad about two miles north of the Israeli border. The police spokesman, who cannot be identified under standing regulations, said the 10 guerrillas, members of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, were spotted by a 30-man Israeli patrol. U.N. security sources said that after the firefight, three Israeli Cobra helicopter gunships flew over the Mariamin Valley near Yater, apparently in search for guerrilla survivors. But no strafing was reported. Later, the Democratic Front issued a communique claiming responsibility for the attack. The communique said machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades were used in the fighting. The battle occurred 12 days after a clash in the same area in which one Palestinian guerrilla was killed and two Israeli soldiers were wounded. The Democratic Front said its fighters were also involved in that clash. The group is a radical flank of Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization. Yater is policed by a Nepalese battalion serving with the U.N. peacekeeping force in South Lebanon. Israeli soldiers later attacked guerrilla targets north of the security zone, destroying a launching pad for assaults on Israel, the Israeli military command said. It added there were no Israeli casualties and did not elaborate. Artillery fire was also aimed at a site in south-central Lebanon, destroying rocket launchers aimed at Israel, the command said. It provided no further details. The Israeli military command said the Yater clash was the 20th this year between Israeli or Israeli-allied forces and guerrillas in Lebanon. In these confrontations, seven soldiers and 43 guerrillas have been killed, the army said. The Israeli-held zone covers 440 square miles from the Mediterranean coast to the foothills of Mount Hermon.

DOC.HEAD: Far From Home, Jewish Sailors in Gulf Region Celebrate Hanukkah
LaserPhoto DHR4
DOC.DATELINE: ABOARD THE USS JOHN F. KENNEDY (AP)
DOC.TEXT: It was an unusual Hanukkah celebration: Jewish sailors on a U.S. aircraft carrier in the Red Sea, lighting menorahs as they sail past Arab countries traditionally hostile to Israel. For the dozen or so Jewish sailors aboard the USS John F. Kennedy, Hanukkah, the festival of lights, has been a time to reflect on their deployment in the Middle East. ``This is where the Jewish people became a people, and on Hanukkah as we light the lights, we recall the suffering and joys of our ancestors as a people,'' said Navy Lt. Robert S. Feinberg, a rabbi from New York, as he led prayers for peace in the Persian Gulf on Friday, the fourth night of Hanukkah. It has also been a time to cast aside worries about war and briefly indulge in some of the joys of Hanukkah - plentiful potato pancakes and games of dreidel, a four-sided spinning top with Hebrew letters on each side. Petty Officer 1st Class Eric Friedman, 33, of Massapequa, N.Y., said he felt he was fighting for the same principle as the Jews did in 167 B.C., when the Maccabees defeated the Syrians and the Temple of Jerusalem was rededicated. Hanukkah commemorates that rededication. ``We're here standing up for freedom against an oppressor,'' he said. ``Of course, my parents would rather have me home, but they're proud of me that I'm serving and standing up for freedom.'' Lt. Toby Bacaner, 31, of Minneapolis, the air wing's flight surgeon, said: ``When the United States goes somewhere, we bring American values with us and we practice them here.'' Petty Officer 3rd Class Michael Shasteen, 23, of Dallas, said Iraq's President Saddam Hussein has to be stopped. ``I know it sounds gung-ho. I'll die for my country. It doesn't bother me. I'll die for something that's right, and I think this is very right,'' he said. The U.S. military has refused to allow the media to attend any religious services in Saudi Arabia, where all religions except Islam are banned. Several reporters visiting the Kennedy were allowed to attend Hanukkah services because the ship is in international waters. The congregation on the Kennedy is led by Chief Petty Officer Sidney Cohen, 41, of Virginia Beach, Va., a senior cook who not only organizes weekly Sabbath services but has taught his staff to make potato pancakes and challah, the traditional Jewish bread. Cohen received a commendation at a Hanukkah dinner Saturday from Rear Adm. Riley D. Mixson, commander of Navy operations in the Red Sea, for his service to the Jewish community. Chief Petty Officer Alfred Lasure, 42, of Vineland, N.J., who works on the flight deck, said that historically the Jews and Arabs are cousins, and if they retraced their roots perhaps they could learn to coexist. For Chief Petty Officer Gary Love, 39, of Birmingham, Ala., the air wing's damage control chief, coming to Hanukkah services was ``a way to be with your family when you're not with your family.'' ``The other night all of us were down on the floor playing with dreidels - a bunch of grown men on the mightiest warship in the Navy playing dreidel,'' he said. The game is traditionally played by children on Hanukkah.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Scholar Sees Unprecedented Dissidence in Albania
With AM-Albania
DOC.TEXT: Anti-government feeling has reached unprecedented levels in Communist Albania and if authorities aren't careful the country could ``go the Romanian route,'' a U.S. scholar said Sunday after spending two weeks there. Nicholas C. Pano, a history professor at Western Illinois University and leading scholar of Albania, was one of only a handful of foreigners who were traveling in the country as it was shaken by violent rioting and political upheaval last week. He described broad changes sweeping Europe's last stronghold of Stalinism - from the playing of Bob Dylan on state radio to the formation of opposition political parties. But he also said that an economic crisis and disgust at official corruption and the country's self-imposed isolation had driven Albanians to the limit. ``I myself was surprised by the strength of feeling, the pent-up anger and desire for change,'' Pano said Sunday, a day after flying from Albania to Italy. ``A few wrong decisions (by the government) could see the whole thing go the Romanian route.'' Romania's Communist government was overthrown last year in a revolution, and its dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu, was executed. Pano, the author of a book on Albania, said numerous changes reflect the government's cautious reforms and citizens' growing boldness in demanding their rights. In the capital city of Tirana, for example, workers at Albania's film studio are discussing forming a political party, he said. Television workers are calling for freedom from state control. Typographers at government-controlled newspapers are talking about establishing the first independent trade union, he said. State media were unusually frank in reporting on rioting in at least four cities last week. Albanians are abuzz about the state radio's recent decision to broadcast part of a Bob Dylan song, Pano said. He didn't know which one. He quoted Albanians as saying that an orchestra in Tirana played George Gershwin's ``Rhapsody in Blue'' a few weeks ago - a real event in a country that long tried to ban most Western influences. The Albanian Communist leadership has this year embarked on a program of cautious reform, including lifting restrictions of religious practice. It had ruled out political pluralism, however, until last week when President Ramiz Alia said the Communist leadership would allow the formation of alternative parties. But Pano, who speaks Albanian, said students and blue-collar workers voiced deep suspicions about authorities' promises of reform. ``Any attempt now (by the government) to turn back would have serious repercussions in the country,'' Pano said. ``The regime could not survive.'' The more radical demands of some students may force a split in the country's first opposition party, the Democratic Party, he said. Among the new party's leaders are middle-aged intellectuals, such as Tirana University Professor Gramoz Pashko, who have been treated well by the government. ``There are some people ... who express concern about what they call `coddled intellectuals,''' said Pano. He attributed the government's ouster of five Politburo members last week to widespread popular dissatisfaction over official incompetence and high living. Albanians are becoming more vocal in objecting to such behavior, he said. For example, in the southern town of Korce, more than 500 people marched to the home of a Communist Party leader on Dec. 9. They demanded to know why he had three cars when they had insufficient bus service, Pano said, citing local witnesses.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Promises Tough Program to Boost Poland
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Lech Walesa on Sunday invoked the memory of shipyard workers killed 20 years ago as he asked Poles to support his future government's policies, saying they will complete the country's reforms. Walesa spoke before a Roman Catholic Mass under the towering monument at the gates of the Gdansk Shipyard, one of the sites along the Baltic coast where dozens of workers were killed in anti-government riots Dec. 16-17 1970. He said his election as president one week ago would help fulfill the slain shipyard workers' dream of a better Poland. ``A huge task awaits us. That is why at this monument to those killed, in this sacred place, I call on all compatriots: Take things in your hands. Don't wait,'' Walesa told 4,000 people attending the nationally televised ceremony held in freezing, windy weather. He promised as president to ``do everything so that you meet as few obstacles as possible on the road of reforms.'' The government he is forming ``will present a program of changes, taking into account your criticisms pronounced during the election campaign.'' ``I don't claim that it will be an easy program. We will lift our country up with the effort of the whole nation. We will fulfil the last will of those killed,'' he pledged. In addition to Polish and Solidarity labor union flags flying at the monument dedicated 10 years ago Sunday, there was a flag of the European Community. Poland is applying for associate membership in the EC and would like to be a full member by the year 2000. Of the workers killed 20 years ago in Gdansk, Gdynia and Szczecin, Walesa said: ``They gave their lives for us. Solidarity was born from their blood.'' Walesa worked as an electrician at the Gdansk Shipyard for nearly two decades. He was chosen by fellow laborers to help lead the bloody 1970 strike to protest food price increases imposed just before the Christmas holiday. It was Walesa's first experience in worker activism. During the 1970s, Walesa faithfully marked the anniversary of the deaths, risking arrest by police who tried to prevent the observances. Recalling those years, Walesa said: ``Today, I am with you as the president-elect. I am able to realize the last will of those who died. ``Free Poland is changing for the better - but too slowly.'' Walesa is scheduled to be sworn in as Poland's first directly elected president Saturday. He is expected almost immediately to nominate a prime minister to replace Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who was rejected by voters for president. On Saturday, Walesa's spokesman Andrzej Drzycimski said that Walesa has authorized lawyer Jan Olszewski to hold talks on forming the government. But he added that it does not necessarily mean Olszewski will get the prime minister's post.

DOC.HEAD: New Archbishop of Armagh Calls For End to IRA Terror
DOC.TEXT: The new spiritual leader of Irish Roman Catholics on Sunday demanded the Irish Republican Army end its two-decade campaign of terror. The Rev. Cahal Daly's harsh comments came at his installation as the new archbishop of Armagh and Primate of All Ireland. Among officials in attendance were Irish President Mary Robinson, Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey and Britain's Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Brooke. ``The longer you continue with your campaign of violence, the more ignominious in the end will be the memory you will leave behind you, and the further away from attainment will be any of your aims and objectives,'' he told the IRA. The predominantly Catholic IRA is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland. Daly, 73, who leads the 3.8 million Roman Catholics in Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic, said the IRA's goals could be attained through peaceful political progress. ``You have no sane reason or justification - moral, rational or political - for continuing with your campaign of violence,'' he told the IRA. ``You have every reason - moral, rational and political - for calling off your campaign now.'' The IRA, which is waging a shooting and bombing campaign to unite the largely Protestant province with the mainly Catholic Republic of Ireland, is opposed by a number of Protestant paramilitary groups, many of them illegal. Daly said there are people in both Catholic and Protestant communities whose consciences are ``blindfolded'' and prevented them seeing the enormity of their violent deeds. The popular overthrow of Communist governments in Eastern Europe last year was primarily a spiritual and moral revolution, he said, and it achieved by peaceful means what armed uprising never could. Daly, the Bishop of Down and Connor since 1982, succeeds Cardinal Tomas O Fiaich, who died in May of a heart attack, aged 66, while on pilgrimage to the shrine of Lourdes, France. His successor was installed at Armagh's St. Patrick's Cathedral, and a number of leading Protestant churchmen was also in attendance. Educated at Queen's University in Belfast and the Institut Catholique in Paris, Daly was ordained in 1941. Daly has become known for his outspokenness against the IRA. In October, at the funeral of a Catholic man mistaken by the IRA for a Protestant, he called the IRA ``the greatest affliction of our community over the past 20 years'' and said membership of the IRA was ``most gravely sinful.'' Around 2,800 people have died in 20 years of sectarian violence in Northern Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Florist Death Spurs More Questions About Dallas Police and Minorities
DOC.TEXT: The fatal shooting of a black florist by a white rookie policeman responding to a burglary call has prompted calls for an investigation and revived talk about racial tensions precipitated by Dallas police. Community leaders' urged a congressional or local independent probe into Friday's slaying of R.L. ``Gunny'' Rose, owner of Veteran's Florist on Dallas' south side. Police said 25-year-old Officer Vincent Reetz mistakenly believed Rose was an assailant. Some say Rose's death is too reminiscent of two other Dallas police killings that ignited racial strife and prompted calls for massive department reforms. In the cases of Etta Collins in 1986 and David Horton in 1987, each victim was black, carrying a gun in self-defense and killed by a white officer. Black leader Roy Williams said the fatal shooting supports his earlier request for an investigation of the Dallas Police Department. ``This is not just an African-American or Latino problem,'' Williams told the Fort Worth Star-Telegram in Sunday's editions. ``This crosses all races and socioeconomic levels. ... The system is broken and we must fix it. But we must act now.'' And City Council member Al Lipscomb, who's black, said he wants an investigation into Rose's shooting and the department's deadly force policy. But police and their supporters say the shooting is just another tragic mistake, unjustly tinged with racial undertones. ``This could have happened to anybody on the department,'' said Sgt. Mike Black, who coordinates field training for rookies. Police officials said Reetz did not hear the 53-year-old man identify himself as the flower shop's owner. ``It was dark out there, and there's a fine line between doing the right thing and doing the wrong thing,'' Black said. ``It's all reaction. ``It's not like on TV when the music is climaxing and then you go to commercial. There, you have a couple of minutes to think about the situation and come up with a solution. This is the real world, and things don't happen that way.'' Rose's store had been broken into twice in the last month. When the alarm went off a third time, at 1:30 a.m. Friday, he arrived at the store before police. He was shot in the chest when he turned, revolver in hand, when he heard Reetz utter a command. ``Mr. Rose's reaction to the command from a police officer was not unreasonable,'' said Deputy Chief Ray Hawkins. ``Unfortunately, when you turn, you bring the weapon to bear. That's the concern we have with people arming themselves.'' Joan Smotzer, co-chairwoman of the Unified Coalition for Police Reforms, noted that Rose had identified himself to Reetz's partner moments before the shooting. If Reetz were unaware of the exchange, as he has told authorities, then it points up the need for better training, Ms. Smotzer said. The death of Mrs. Collins, 70, prompted a congressional hearing in April 1987 that focused on the history of strained relations between minorities and Dallas police. The next month, David Horton, 81, was shot to death while investigating a car theft in the parking lot of his apartment building. Police Chief Billy Prince, who blamed City Council critics for creating ``a negative atmosphere'' that led to violence against officers, resigned under pressure the following year. Mack Vines, billed as a reformer, took the helm in mid-1988 and quickly promoted minority officers into top jobs. In 1989, the civilian review board was given limited powers to investigate allegations of police wrongdoing. Vines himself was fired early this year for lying about a shooting inquiry.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Officials Perplexed by Disappearance of PCBs at Hazardous Waste Site
DOC.TEXT: Environmental Protection Agency officials say they're stumped by the disappearance of PCBs from a hazardous waste site that once had high concentrations of the cancer-causing substance. Polychlorinated biphenyls, once used as insulators in electrical transformers, were banned by the federal government in the 1970s. They have not been known to break down in the environment and have been considered nearly impossible to destroy. But officials say a lagoon at the former Cam-Or oil re-refinery site - which once contained more than triple the concentration of PCBs allowed by law - now appears free of the contaminants. EPA spokeswoman Sue Pastor said agency officials are studying the site to find out what happened. The EPA cited Cam-Or in January 1985 for PCBs in three of 11 waste oil lagoons. The company filed for bankruptcy two years later. Jack Barnette, an EPA supervisor for emergency response, helped oversee a containment and temporary cleanup project in which crews combined the three infested lagoons, drained and treated the wastewater, and added lime to help harden the waste. The EPA then covered the new lagoon with a tarp to prevent rain from washing contaminants out of it. When EPA officials returned to test the lagoon in mid-1988, they found the oil sludge intact but the PCBs gone, Barnette said. Well water monitoring around the site shows the chemicals did not seep out of the lagoon, he said. Officials say the PCBs appear to have disintegrated into harmless chemical components. Barnette said the leading theory is that high heat and low moisture during a long drought in 1988 combined to disintegrate the contaminants. Lime used to harden the sludge may have also helped break down the PCBs, but so far there is no scientific evidence to prove it, Barnette said. At a similar site in Toledo, Ohio, where the EPA began a cleanup effort just after the one at Cam-Or, lime was used to harden sludge and the PCBs also disappeared. ``We are not sure if it was the environment or the lime or the combination, but from now on we'll be using lime when we deal with PCBs,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Haitians Eager to Vote, But Many Encounter Delays
With AM-Haiti, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - Frustration replaced fear among many Haitians who overcame worries of election violence Sunday - but confronted long voting delays. ``Nothing would keep me from voting,'' said 25-year-old Jean Elie, standing in line at a school to vote in the effort to hold Haiti's first fully democratic elections in history. Ballots and ballot boxes were late arriving at many polling stations. At one, no ballots had arrived by noon, six hours after the official start of voting. Some election delegates said they also lacked pens, ink and registration lists. In general, Haitians shrugged off the possibility that a 1987 Election Day massacre would be repeated. That election was called off after thugs with machetes, knives and guns killed at least 34 voters. Many voters rode bicycles or walked for miles, arriving before dawn and waiting for the polls to open. In the Cite Soleil slum, where thousands live in ramshackle huts and bathe in open sewers, voters grew impatient and began waving their registration cards in the air after many polls failed to open on time. ``Hurry up, please let us in,'' a chorus of people standing outside a school pleaded with election officials. When some voters began waving branches, the traditional symbol of celebration or protest, 50 riot police arrived to block any attempt to start a demonstration. ``We have a lot of help, but not enough,'' said Daniel Bernier, in charge of the elections in western Haiti. ``We don't have enough cars (to deliver supplies).'' His office was stacked with undelivered ballots and folded ballot boxes. Outside, workers were rushing them onto a truck. Some who failed to register expressed regret. ``I saw what happened last time. I lost two cousins and my aunt was wounded here. But now I feel sorry not to be voting,'' said Fleury Margella, 25, who tried to vote in 1987 at the Argentine Bellegrade secondary school, where 14 were slain in the election massacre. At the school, only two of the 19 voting booths were open two hours after polls opened Sunday. Some of the nearly 1,000 international observers noted Haitian's interim government had been little time to prepare for elections, announced in September. ``There are going to be glitches all over,'' said J. Michael Levesque, mayor of West Warwick, R.I., who is one of eight observers sent by President Bush. ``But when you see people standing in long lines in the hot sun ... it's remarkable.'' Most of the poor in the capital of Port-au-Prince appeared to support the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a leftist priest considered the front-runner among a field of 11 presidential candidates. Many voiced suspicion that the delays were deliberate and intended to keep them from voting. Aristide was an ardent critic of the Duvalier family dictatorship that ruled Haiti for 29 years, and holdovers from the regime had vowed to keep him out of the presidency. In Gonaives, about 105 miles northwest of the capital, peasant organizations said small rice and bean farmers backed Aristide. They said army officers met with city leaders to try to turn voters against Aristide. Others in Gonaives with ties to the Duvaliers were not so enthusiastic about Aristide. ``There will be no Titid (diminutive for Aristide) for president. ... It's impossible. You'll see. The country needs a moderate man,'' said Zacharie Delva, once a leader of the Tonton Macoutes, the feared private militia used by the Duvalier regime.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Interrogations of Store Employees Stopped
DOC.TEXT: A convience store chain accused of pressuring employees into admitting theft has stopped the interrogations, according to store employees and attorneys. Cumberland Farms, which has 1,200 stores and hundreds of gas stations in 11 states, has denied the allegations. Store employees and attorneys indicate that no Cumberland Farms cashiers have been interrogated or asked to sign a confession since September, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported Sunday. The newspaper has reported that since 1976, 30,000 employees have been fired after being questioned, and hundreds said they paid money to the company, from 59 cents to $14,000, after being falsely accused. The publicity has prompted the convenience-store company to ``change its ways,'' said Lynn Aaby, a public defender in New Hampshire. ``The numbers have literally gone to zero,'' said Michael Rubin, assistant state attorney for Martin County, Fla., whose office handled many Cumberland Farms theft cases in four years. Cumberland Farms vice president Foster Macrides has said the company never had a policy of coercing employees. Former employees have filed three civil lawsuits against the Canton, Mass.,-based company, including one in Camden, N.J., that charges the company's policy was to make up for inventory losses by accusing employees of stealing and forcing them to pay.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion Reported at Sears; Store Evacuated
DOC.TEXT: An explosion Sunday afternoon inside a Sears store at a shopping mall forced evacuation of the store, but caused no injuries and little damage, police said. Authorities believe that a stick of dynamite inside a refrigerator on display in the store's major-appliances department caused it. No other store at the Tri-County Mall was evacuated. Springdale police Lt. Jeff Hermann described the explosion as minor and said only the refrigerator was damaged. He said no other explosive devices had been found. He did not know the means of detonation. James Freland, the police chief in this community about 12 miles northeast of Cincinnati in southwestern Ohio, said police had no suspects or motive. The store was closed after the blast, and employees were sent home for the day, police said. Hermann said that Sears had not received any threat before the explosion. No threats were received at the Springdale Police or Hamilton County Sheriff's departments.

DOC.HEAD: Suspects Arrested in Albanian Riots to Face Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with trials planned for those arrested. Picks up 6th grafs pvs, `Last week ....' TRIMS thereafter
DOC.TEXT: Albanian authorities will bring to trial more than 150 people arrested during a wave of riots in that country, Europe's last Stalinist nation, official Albanian radio reported Sunday. Radio Tirana said the trials for the 157 detainees could begin as early as Monday. Albanian chief investigator Chemal Lame was quoted as saying the rioters faced charges ranging from illegal assembly to theft and inflicting injury, according to the Yugoslav news agency Tanjug, which monitored the broadcast. The radio did not say what penalties the defendants could face. At least 16 people were injured and many buildings and vehicles were damaged in the unrest. The report said 60 people were arrested in the northern city of Shkodra Thursday, and 55 people were detained in the central city of Elbasan, which was racked by violence Friday. Another 42 people were detained in the central coastal city of Durres, the radio said, according to Tanjug, monitored in Vienna. The British Broadcasting Corp. said it monitored a similar report in London. The country was reported quiet Sunday and troops have been withdrawn, a journalist for Albania's state news agency said from Tirana, the capital. The journalist said the normal number of police now patrolled the cities of Skhodra, Elbasan, Durres and Kavaje, the centers of the rioting. Communist President Ramiz Alia on Saturday condemned the violence and said such ``criminal activity'' would not be tolerated. Also Sunday, a spokesman for Albania's first non-Communist party said it plans to seek formal registration with the government this week to contest parliamentary elections. Last week, the Communists, for the first time since taking power in 1944, announced they would allow the formation of alternative parties. The leadership apparently bowed to pressure by protesting students in the capital. On Wednesday, students, intellectuals and others founded the first such party to the cheers of thousands of supporters at a rally and said they hoped to compete in parliamentary elections set for Feb. 10. Genc Pollo, a spokesman for the new Democratic Party of Albania, said the party would seek registration with the government as early as Monday. He said the new party also sought to postpone the parliamentary vote to give it more time to campaign. Pollo said Parliament was expected to issue a decree on the formation of parties, also as early as Monday.
