According to the decree, the government would have 30 days to reply to a registration request, he said. Gramoz Paskho, an economist and leader of the new party, said in a telephone interview that the government must formally approve the new party to show that it serious about promises of reform. ``It will show the Albanian people and the rest of the world it is a serious government if it does what it promises,'' he said. ``If they delay it, they will create a kind of impasse.'' Although the party is only five days old, it appeared already to have widespread support. Pollo said in a telephone interview from Tirana that it has been receiving letters of support from prominent scholars, artists and writers. He said the party estimated that it has the support of about 20,000 people in the tiny country of 3.2 million. The Communist Party claims more than 120,000 members.

DOC.HEAD: New Journal Offers Sexuality Studies for the Scholarly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `For instance ...' to remove typo in `Joshua.' Picks up 15th graf, `There aren't ...'
DOC.TEXT: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. (AP) - There is sex galore in this magazine. There is homosexuality and bisexuality and bestiality and miscegenation and just about every other permutation of sexual conduct known to men and women. But don't contact the authorities. The treatment these sensational topics receive in the gray pages of the Journal of the History of Sexuality is more likely to send the average reader to a thesaurus than a cold shower. ``It's scholars talking to other scholars about research and important scholarly studies using all of the methodology and approaches that are used in social science research,'' said Robert Shirrell of the University of Chicago Press, publisher of the journal. ``It's not going to be, nor would it serve its function if it were, a publication for a general audience.'' Articles in the first two issues covered such subjects as ``Holy Harlots,'' a study of prostitute saints in medieval Europe; the homosexual habits of actors on the 18th century London stage; and early writings and research on syphilis in 15th and 16th century England. Studies of Old Norse sexuality and marriage rituals in modern-day Morocco have been lined up for future issues. The quarterly journal is edited by John Fout, 53, a professor of modern European history at Bard College, a small liberal arts school 100 miles north of New York City. While researching sexual politics topics such as the forced sterilization policies of Nazi Germany, Fout said he discovered no journal on sex was devoted to the works of scholar-authors like himself. Studies in the field were dominated instead by sexologists - researchers like Masters and Johnson doing medically based studies of sexual behavior - or by pyschologists working on the mental aspects of sexuality, Fout said. He said he decided to start a new journal that would ``publish the best and the newest and the most critical theoretical scholarship from scholars around the world.'' The journal, which debuted in July, is the 51st scholarly publication produced by the University of Chicago Press. Fout said the works in his journal represent a largely new and unconventional way of looking at the sexual history of mankind. Most of the study of human sexuality during the past generation has centered on ``how the body works,'' he said. The studies in his journal examine instead the way sexual behavior has been molded by the influences within society and culture, such as religion, politics and government. For instance, an article in the second issue of the journal explores the condom's struggle for legal and social acceptance in 20th century America. Author Joshua Gamson said his research only ``peripherally'' deals with sex, and that it might have been difficult to get his piece published in a science-based sexual journal. ``There aren't many places where I could have placed an article on condoms,'' said Gamson, 27, a doctoral student at the University of California, Berkeley. The journal does not pay contributors. Scholars whose articles or book reviews are published are offered 10 free copies of the issue or a year's free subscription, an arrangement that Fout said is standard for such publications. So far, the journal has about 1,000 paid subscribers, respectable for a first-year publication, Shirrell said. Most copies can be found in college libraries. Fout said a few bookstores have agreed to sell the journal. ``We undertake publications with the expectation that they will continue indefinitely,'' Shirrell said. ``This is going to be an important area for academic research for a number of years.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Remains Hopeful He Can Go To Baghdad To Discuss Gulf Crisis
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Sunday he still hopes to revive the stalled American proposal for talks with Saddam Hussein. He said he wants to travel to Baghdad to see Iraqi President Saddam by Jan. 3 at the latest to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis. But he gave no indication Saddam was about to agree to any of 15 dates, from Dec. 20 through Jan. 3, that the administration says it has proposed for a Baghdad meeting. ``We hope something can be arranged,'' Baker said of stalled efforts for U.S.-Iraq talks. He added, ``There is no back channel talking going on'' with Baghdad. And he would not comment on what diplomatic moves he was planning to secure a visit to Baghdad, except to say, ``Stay tuned.'' Bush's meeting Monday with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Washington has been put off due to Saddam's refusal to set an early date for a return visit by Baker. Saddam has offered to meet Baker Jan. 12, three days before the U.N deadline for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait or face military force. President Bush proposed the high-level talks, saying he hopes to discuss Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. But Iraq says it intends to keep Kuwait, which it invaded Aug. 2. Baker's remarks were contained in a transcript of comments he made to reporters as he flew to Brussels for a two-day NATO foreign ministers meeting. He said that at the NATO meeting, which starts Monday, he will discuss the Persian Gulf crisis with the allies and appeal for additional help in moving U.S. troops and materiel to the gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Investigation Clears Naval Officer in Fraternization Case
DOC.TEXT: A commanding officer at the Orlando Naval Training Center has been cleared of accusations he was dating a lower-ranking female sailor in violation of military policy. A naval investigation found no evidence to support allegations that Cmdr. John Fullerton was having an improper relationship with a third-class petty officer, said Rear Adm. Louise Wilmot, commanding officer of the center. Wilmot spent six hours Saturday interviewing Fullerton, the unidentified woman and eight other people before reaching her conclusion, a base spokeswoman said. Navy rules prohibit officers from dating enlisted personnel and ban social contact between students and instructors. The training center is under investigation by the Pentagon for its handling of sexual assault cases and enforcement of rules concerning social relationships. Fullerton, 41, was transferred to other duties at the Naval and Marine Corps Reserve Center in Orlando during the inquiry. He will return to his post Monday as second in command of the division that handles housing, food recreation and other services. Lt. Cmdr. Nettie Johnson, a base spokeswoman, said Friday that an anonymous caller to the base legal department hotline accused Fullerton of having a long-term relationship with the female sailor. The caller also alleged that at a party on Nov. 24 he got into a hot tub with ``seminude'' women. Both Fullerton, who is married, and the female petty officer denied any romantic involvement Fullerton was at the party and acknowledged getting into the hot tub but witnesses said everyone was appropriately clothed. Fullerton was not immediately available for comment, but according to Johnson, ``he said he and his wife were exhausted from the ordeal and they are glad it's over.'' A high-level Navy probe in July criticized the Naval Investigative Service for the way it treated some women rape victims at the training center during questioning. The NIS is the Navy's investigative arm. The report, however, noted the Wilmot - who once headed the Navy's equal opportunity office for women - has improved the working climate and health benefits for female sailors since taking command of the base in May 1989. Last week, a military judge ordered four male instructors to stand trial on charges that they dated or made sexual advances toward students or recruits. A second team of Pentagon investigators was scheduled Monday to begin a survey of all female employees at the base to determine whether sexual harassment or improper relationships is an large problem there.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Offers 500 Tons of Dates to Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has offered 500 tons of dates to the Soviet Union as part of international efforts to help tide the Soviets through the winter, the official news agency said Sunday. The Iraqi News Agency quoted the chairman of the Iraqi Red Crescent, Dr. Ibrahim al-Nouri, as saying the organization's offer came ``as a gift from the Iraqi people to the Soviet people out of the spirit of traditional friendship between the two peoples.'' The news agency, which is monitored in Nicosia, said the Soviets had been made aware of the offer but had not responded. The Soviets expect severe food shortages during the winter, and many Western countries, including the United States, have responded with an outpouring of aid. This is the first reported offer of aid from Iraq, which was Moscow's main Middle East ally and received much of its weaponry from the Soviet Union before its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Since the invasion, the two nations have been at odds.

DOC.HEAD: Once-Ballyhooed Condos Go On Block
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `The units ...,' to CORRECT to 32 stories, sted 38; Pick up 3rd graf, ``We far ...'
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump got some help with a mortgage Sunday by auctioning 35 luxury waterfront condominiums overlooking the ritz and fame of this high-society resort. The units in the twin 32-story towers at Trump Plaza of the Palm Beaches sold for $8.815 million, 24 percent above the total asking price. However, the asking prices had been slashed by up to two-thirds. ``We far exceeded our expectations today. This was a tremendous sale for Trump Plaza,'' Trump said. ``I think it could work out to be a very good deal, depending on what ultimately happens with the final numbers.'' Previous asking prices of $300,960 to $1.8 million for the penthouse were trimmed to minimum bids of $150,000 to $600,000 under pressure from Marine Midland Bank. The bank wanted Trump to unload the units that had gone unsold since the developer took over the building in 1986, boasting the complex would be Florida's hottest property. Developer Ian Kean of nearby Singer Island bought the penthouse for $720,000. The building's biggest drawback, local real estate experts say, is location. The property is on the wrong side of the Intracoastal Waterway in this prestige-conscious neighborhood. The auction took place on the right side - in a chandelier-bedecked ballroom at The Breakers, a grand dame hotel on this barrier island. Trump's 118-room Mar-a-Lago weekend retreat is also on the more prestigous side of the waterway. About 85 of the 221 units remain vacant or unsold. Officials said Trump made the decision not to auction all units, and said no decision had been made on their disposal. Trump missed a $27.1 million payment Oct. 22 to Marine Midland, which loaned him the money to buy the building. In a restructuring agreement in August, Trump's lenders pushed him into the auction because sales had been so sluggish. Only one sale had been recorded this year. As the auction catalog says, ``glorious sun-drenched days evolve into dazzling moonlit nights'' at the towers overlooking the waterway and this resort town. The Trump Plaza has a sumptuous lobby with walls of marble and leather, a concierge, valet parking, morning and afternoon pools, sunning terraces, a fitness center and tennis courts. But the units are largely unfinished. ``I think that was disappointing, because that was not announced prior to our coming down here,'' said Bobbe Jacobson, of Boston, a professional party planner. Trump is also due to make $34.5 million in payments to bondholders who invested in two of his Atlantic City casinos. The formal deadline for the $18.4 million payment on the Trump Castle and a $16.1 million payment on the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino was Saturday, but Trump was given until Monday to cover the bills because of the weekend. If he fails to meet the deadlines Monday, he will be given a 10-day grace period to turn over the bond money on Trump Castle. He would also have 30 days to make the payment on the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino.

DOC.HEAD: Official: One-Third Of Eastern Germans Will Be Short of Work
DOC.TEXT: An official said in a newspaper interview Sunday that one-third of the workers in former East Germany will be jobless or working reduced hours this summer. Reiner Herbst, chief of the employment agency responsible for the former nation, told the Berliner Morgenpost that 3 million of the roughly 8.8 million workers will have lost their jobs by this summer or will be working shorter hours at lower pay. As of November, about 600,000 workers were officially unemployed. Independent economists have said joblessness could reach 3 million to 4 million next year. East Germany converted from a socialist economy to a free market on July 1 and unified with West Germany on Oct. 3. Many enterprises will either close or reduce payrolls because of the new Western competition. Herbst said he believes the job market will begin to pick up in 1992 after new Western investment moves in. The government is counting on Western capitalists to fill the employment void created by the collapse of former state-run enterprises.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Announces Cabinet Resignation Under Pressure
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino, under public pressure to shore up the economy, on Sunday announced the resignation of her trade minister. However, she said calls for her to step down are ``figments of the imagination'' of her enemies. In a nationwide television address, Mrs. Aquino said Secretary Jose Concepcion handed in his resignation Tuesday but would be retained until Jan. 2 to help the country through its economic crisis. No replacement was named. Political sources, speaking on condition of nonymity, said other Cabinet changes are expected. Mrs. Aquino acknowledged she was bowing to public pressure for changes in her administration after a stunning 45 percent increase in fuel prices coupled with a declining economy. ``I've told him that what I'm doing is in response to grievances of some sectors in our society,'' she said of Concepcion. ``It is truly difficult to be separated from familiar friends, especially those who have proven their faith and conviction.'' Concepcion played no major role in the price increase. But he had been under fire for allegedly failing to divest holdings in family businesses which prospered under the Aquino administration. Mrs. Aquino noted that a Senate panel cleared Concepcion of wrongdoing. She said nonetheless that she was accepting his resignation to help maintain national harmony. Concepcion's resignation followed the replacement of Mrs. Aquino's executive secretary, Catalino Macaraig, who had also served as the government's energy coordinator. In her remarks Sunday, Mrs. Aquino also acknowledged opposition calls for her to resign or call early elections. Four of the 23 senators, including three elected on the administration ticket, have joined those calls. ``The call for the resignation of the president has no meaning or significance but are figments of the imagination of people who thrive on illusions,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Central American Presidents Condemn Salvadoran Fighting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with statement against Salvadoran rebels. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Cristiani, who ...' edits to conform
DOC.TEXT: Central American leaders agreed Sunday to a statement condemning a new offensive by rebels in El Salvador's 11-year civil war. ``We cannot condone the Salvadoran guerrillas' unleashing of indiscriminate violence, just at a time when an end to it is being sought through dialogue and negotiation,'' Costa Rican President Rafael Calderon said. He said the five Central American presidents at the summit will make a proposal Monday to the rebel Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front to resume peace talks with President Alfredo Cristiani's government. Earlier Sunday, Cristiani pressed other leders to issue the anti-rebel statement. The guerrilla offensive has dominated the meeting of Central American presidents, who have also discussed economic issues and plans to invite Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev to visit the region. The three-day meeting is scheduled to conclude Monday. Cristiani, who leads a right-wing government, has said repeatedly that his government is willing to meet with the rebels, but formal negotiations ended in September without significant progress. In other issues, summit participants said Nicaraguan President Violeta Chamorro will deliver the invitation to Gorbachev to come to Central America when she visits Moscow in February. Also attending the conference are Guatemalan President Vinicio Cerezo and President Leonardo Callejas of Honduras. President Guillermo Endara of Panama attended as an observer. In the final communique, the presidents also are expected to call for international action to protect the environment, elimination of visas for diplomats and businessmen traveling in the region, and strengthening the U.N. peacekeeping mission in Central America.

DOC.HEAD: Miami's Haitian Exiles Rally as Island Votes
With AM-Haiti, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Haitians rallied in the streets of Miami's Little Haiti on Sunday, cheering for their favorite candidates and closely monitoring the first fully free presidential elections in their homeland. The crowd overwhelmingly favored the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, a populist priest who has the admiration of many Haitians here. They said Aristide represents a different class and background than Haiti's line of upper-class, suppressive leaders, and will bring real change. ``Today we need a president that we can put all our trust in (so) that Haitians will have a better tomorrow,'' said Jacqui Prime as a crowd estimated by Haitians at more than 4,000 danced, carried posters and chanted Aristide's name. Miami police could not provide a crowd estimate. ``Public schools, hospitals ... we want it for the Haitian kids,'' said Mona Michel. ``(Aristide) will negotiate with the foreign governments for us, not for his pocket.'' Aristide campaigned in Miami on Nov. 2, drawing support from more than 7,000 people. Haitians in Miami, where the largest number of immigrants came around 1980, now number more than 100,000. Marc Bazin, a former World Bank official seen as Aristide's closest rival and a favorite of Haiti's business community, drew far smaller crowds during his campaign stop in Miami. Some Haitians returned home in recent weeks to vote, many have contributed money to presidential candidates, and most also have influence with relatives and friends at home who may be impressed with how candidates are viewed and reported upon in this country. Tension was also high in Little Haiti in light of the violent break-up of a rally by Aristide on Dec. 5 in Haiti and the Election Day massacre three years ago in which at least 34 people were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Greek Prisoners Stage Mass Escape
DOC.TEXT: Police launched a nationwide manhunt Sunday for more than 65 inmates following the second recent mass jailbreak from an overcrowded prison. A police spokesman said 15 of the 81 prisoners who broke out of Korydallos prison Saturday had been recaptured by late Sunday. The escapees were mostly ``burglars and thieves'' and did not include maximum-security prisoners including convicted murderers, suspect terrorists and some of Greece's most notorious felons. Lack of jail space has forced police to use the prison for general inmates and as a holding facility for suspects awaiting trial. Korydallos, located in the port city of Piraeus near Athens, houses about 800 prisoners. The spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the escape was the largest ever in Greece. According to the spokesman, the escape began when inmates overpowered some guards and took their keys. ``They couldn't unlock the (kitchen) door so they tore it off its hinges and escaped through the psychiatric ward whose gates were unlocked,'' he said. Police guards fired machine gun volleys over the heads of fleeing prisoners, the spokesman said. ``They didn't have shoot-to-kill orders,'' he said. Police arrested eight inmates on the spot. More than 20 prisoners escaped from the prison during a 28-day uprising that ended on Nov. 12. They were all recaptured. Mohammed Rashid, a Palestinian suspected of planting a bomb aboard a Pan American World Airways jet in 1982, has been held at Korydallos since his arrest in 1988. Rashid will be tried in Greece although the United States asked for his extradition. Leaders of the 1967-74 military dictatorship are serving life terms in a separate wing of the prison. They did not take part in the jail break.

DOC.HEAD: Simulator Teaching Marine Reservists How to Fight in the Desert
DOC.NOTE: Eds:SUBS 7th graf,`It then ...' to RESTORE dropped first reference to Marlin. Picks up 8th graf, `The Marines' ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-America Gives, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Many Marine reservists activated for duty in the Persian Gulf have never trained for desert warfare, so the corps is bringing the desert to them. Reservists joining Operation Desert Shield will get a taste of how to fight in the desert from a laser video being produced for a special simulator. ``There are substantial differences ... as to the way things appear in the desert,'' said Maj. Lowell Grubbs, an assistant training officer at the 4th Marine Division in New Orleans. ``Distances are hard to estimate; it's a flat terrain with little cover.'' Firearms Training Systems Inc., based in the Atlanta suburb of Norcross, is producing the video for use with its simulator, which 36 Marine Reserve Centers already use. Before Iraq invaded Kuwait in August, the company had mainly provided video rifle ranges or green environments for Marines to practice with the simulator, shooting in jungles they likely would face in southeast Asia or Central America. The desert video, completed this month, will go first to the 4th Marine Division, said Grubbs, who participated in the filming. It then will be distributed to other Marine reserve centers by the beginning of next month. It may go to Saudi Arabia for use by Marines already stationed there, said Jeff Marlin, a spokesman for Firearms Training Systems Inc. The Marines' simulators, which cost $70,000 apiece, consist of a computer that projects a video onto a large screen. Speakers provide background noise. Squadrons of four soldiers at a time shoot at the screen with M-16 rifles, which are rigged to simulate gunshots. ``It touches a lot of your senses,'' Grubbs said. An instructor sits at the computer acting as commanding officer. ``There's still a lot of human impact on this system - it's not a video game,'' he said. After the simulation, the instructor rewinds the video and each soldier's shots - represented on the film by numbered dots - are reviewed. Grubbs said the simulators are more realistic than regular rifle ranges with pop-up cardboard targets. ``People move differently than cardboard targets,'' he said. ``It takes different techniques to actually hit a moving person.' With this video, soldiers will also practice firing while wearing gas masks, in case they face chemical warfare in Iraq. Marlin said the video also includes a shoot-don't shoot scenario in which the Marines must decide if people rapidly appearing are a threat or innocent civilians, adding, ``They may have to go into Kuwait City and will be faced with that situation.'' He put the cost of the training at ``less than one-tenth of a cent a round ... plus it's right in the classroom.''

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Aliens Protest in Detention Center
DOC.TEXT: More than 300 illegal Chinese aliens banged pots and shouted slogans Monday during a protest in an overcrowded military detention camp to demand immediate repatriation to China. The Taiwan Garrison Command, a military agency, said the protest was under way at the detention center in Lotung, 43 miles southeast of Taipei. It is the largest of four such centers for illegal Chinese aliens. Television broadcasts showed inmates banging the barred windows and shouting ``Let us return!'' and ``Reporters help us!'' early Monday while about 200 military police ran into the center. The military agency declined to say if the situation was under control. Local newspapers said the Chinese requested immediate repatriation in the same boats they used to come to Taiwan. The reports quoted the Chinese as saying that if they were returned to China on Taiwanese boats they would be fined by Chinese authorities. They also demanded better housing while in Taiwan. It was the second day of protests at the center. On Sunday, the inmates refused to eat and overturned tables to demand immediate repatriation. The Chinese entered Taiwan illegally to work at jobs that pay more than on the Communist mainland. Authorities estimate more than 10,000 Chinese have sneaked into Taiwan since 1987, when the Nationalist government ended 38 years of martial law and eased restrictions on contacts between Taiwan and China. The two territories have technically been at war since 1949, when Communist Chinese forces chased Nationalist Chinese troops from mainland China to the island of Taiwan. Red Cross associations in Taiwan and China supervise the repatriation program. Taiwan's Red Cross Association said about 600 Chinese were being kept in detention centers in Taiwan. It urged its counterpart in China to expedite the screening of aliens for repatriation.

DOC.HEAD: Honeywell Investigated on Possible Sale of Missile Guidance System to Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon is investigating whether Honeywell plans for a sophisticated missile guidance system were sold to Iraq through a Swiss arms broker, a newspaper reported Sunday. The Star Tribune said it was unknown whether the Honeywell technology is in the hands of the Iraqis, who have been scavenging Western defense technology for at least six years, defense experts said. ``We're looking into everything and anything Honeywell may have done transferring technology to Iraq,'' Defense Department spokesman Rick Oborn said last week. The guidance system could give any missile deadly precision, and weapons experts said the possibility of Iraq possessing that technology could be more worrisome than its purchase of a study for a bomb called a fuel-air explosive. It was reported two weeks ago that Iraq obtained the 300-page technical study made by the Minneapolis-based defense contractor in 1984 for $100,000 in a deal with IFAT, a Swiss arms broker. Pentagon sources told the Star Tribune last week that they are investigating Honeywell to determine whether one of its executives sold plans for a ring laser gyroscope to IFAT in 1984. The device, which employs lasers and mirrors, can be used to guide aircraft as well as missiles. It is considered the heart of Honeywell guidance systems. Weapons experts speculate that the Iraqis would employ the technology with missiles loaded with either chemical weapons or explosives such as the fuel-air explosive. Iraq also has been working on a nuclear bomb, intelligence sources say. Honeywell acknowledged that investigators from the Defense Technology Security Administration met with company officials Tuesday to discuss the bomb study and other possible sales to IFAT. Pentagon officials asked the company to look for documents that would indicate whether plans for the ring laser gyroscope were sold to IFAT. ``We have not been able to find any information to support that inertial guidance technology was transferred to IFAT,'' Honeywell spokeswoman Susan Eich said Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Haiti Votes Peacefully, Aristide Supporters Celebrate
LaserPhoto PAP1,2,4
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with observer predicting Aristide victory, quotes from head of Electoral Council; pickup graf 3 pvs `About 200....' No official results expected before noon Monday.
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - Haitians voted peacefully Sunday as nearly 1,000 international observers monitored elections that appeared to be the most democratic ever in Haiti. Some backers of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide celebrated, claiming their candidate won. One international observer said most of the foreign poll-watchers believe Aristide, a leftist priest, had won, though the first official results were not expected until noon Monday. The observer said their belief was based on what they had seen of voting results, but he provided no numbers. He spoke on condition of anonymity. Jean-Robert Sabalat, president of the independent Electoral Council, declared, ``The voters participated in the electoral process with an exemplary calm, which one of our visitors called the ``Haitian miracle.' ``This time the army was equal to its task,'' he said. He thanked international observers for their help and said, ``We have just lived together a great day in our history.'' Supporters of the Aristide, who had been considered a front-runner, took to the streets Sunday night in at least one area of downtown Port-au-Prince to celebrate what they regarded as his sure victory as president. About 200 people, many chanting Aristide's name and dancing in the streets, took part in the early victory celebration. The celebration appeared confined to that area, however. No violent incidents were reported through the day, but there appeared to be some major delays. Some polling stations were kept open after the 6 p.m. closing time. Police and soldiers with automatic weapons guarded many polling places Port-au-Prince, the capital, seeking to avoid a repeat of an Election Day massacre three years ago in which at least 34 people were killed. The international airport remained open but airlines canceled scheduled arriving flights in case of disturbances. Ismael Diallo, a spokesman for a U.N. observer team, said Sunday night that voting apparently was peaceful throughout the country and there appeared to have been a large turnout. ``The armed forces and the security forces have been very professional,'' Diallo said. Given Haiti's violent history, he said: ``It's really very, very positive.'' However, he said long delays occurred in many areas because of difficulty in distributing voting materials. Police in riot gear were deployed in the sprawling slum of Cite Soleil after polling stations in the area opened several hours late. About 50 police blocked a highway to stop what appeared to be the start of a march downtown by hundreds of angry residents, many waving cut branches, a traditional symbol of protest or celebration. However, there were no clashes. The seaside slum is a stronghold of support for Aristide, and many residents blamed his opponents for the delay in distributing ballots and ballot boxes. Five hours after polls were to open, voting had begun in only one of 50 polling stations in the area. ``It is either lack of preparation by the Electoral Council, or sabotage,'' said Shiller Marcellin, president of a large labor federation. Election officials, however, attributed the delays to logistical problems. ``We've had a lot of (international) help, but not enough,'' said Daniel Bernier, the district election bureau director, whose office was cluttered with undelivered ballots and ballot boxes. He said he did not have enough trucks distribute voting materials. No results from the nation's 14,500 polling stations were expected before noon Monday because of poor communications, the Electoral Council said. Nearly 3 million people, or 85 percent of the electorate, were registered to vote. The election was monitored by about 800 international observers, including former President Jimmy Carter. Carter arrived early at the Argentine Bellegrade secondary school, where thugs protected by the army shot and hacked to death 14 voters on Nov. 29, 1987. At least 20 others were gunned down in the streets, giving the military regime of that time a pretext for calling off the election. Subsequent elections in January 1988 were controlled by the army and boycotted by most of the main contenders in 1987. ``We wanted to come here as a symbolic thing to show the people of Haiti that it's safe to vote today,'' said Carter, who was accompanied by his wife, Rosalynn, and daughter, Amy. Several voters waiting to cast ballots in the ramshackle school building and open-air classrooms said they were not afraid. ``No, I came with all my heart,'' said Sander Destine, 27, when asked if he feared violence. ``I'm happy to have elections. I'm happy to have a leader,'' he said, referring to Aristide. Aristide, 37, a leftist Roman Catholic priest with a huge following among the majority poor, was widely regarded as the most popular of 11 presidential candidates. Expectations of an Aristide victory were running so high that some feared disturbances if he failed to win. If no candidate wins more than 50 percent of the vote, a runoff is to be held on Jan. 20. The new government will replace the caretaker administration of President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, a Supreme Court justice appointed in March to lead Haiti to democratic elections. Aristide, dressed all in white, cast his ballot at the capital's Claire Heureuse secondary school. He was mobbed by supporters, some jubilantly mimicking the crow of a rooster, his campaign symbol. Marc Bazin, 58, a former World Bank official seen as Aristide's closest rival and a favorite of the business community, was voting in Petionville, a suburb where a grenade-and-gun attack on Dec. 5 left seven dead and more than 50 wounded at an Aristide campaign rally. Despite fears that supporters of the 29-year Duvalier dictatorship would disrupt the election, the Dec. 5 attack was the only election-related violence during the campaign, which began in October. The president is to be inaugurated on Feb. 7, 1991, the fifth anniversary of the fall of Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier, whose father, Francois ``Papa Doc,'' died in 1971. Haitians also were electing 110 members of a bicameral National Assembly, 134 mayors, 268 municipal council members and 1,695 county officials. The impoverished nation of 6 million people has been ruled almost exclusively by dictators since gaining independence from France in 1804 after a slave revolt. Since the younger Duvalier fled into exile in France after a popular uprising, the country has been ruled by five different governments. The international observers also included representatives from the United Nations and the Organization of American States. It was the first time the United Nations had granted a request by a member nation to oversee its election.

DOC.HEAD: Polly Peck's Asil Nadir Charged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS date of court appearance to Monday, sted Tuesday, in 2nd graf, `The 48-year-old ...' Picks up 3rd graf, `In a brief ...'
DOC.TEXT: Asil Nadir, chairman and chief executive officer of the troubled Polly Peck empire, was charged Sunday with 18 offenses of theft and false accounting. The 48-year-old Turkish-Cypriot businessman, who was arrested Saturday at Heathrow Airport as he arrived from Turkey, is to appear before Bow Street magistrates court Monday, police said. In a brief statement outside London's Holborn police station where Nadir was being questioned, Detective Superintendent David Staff of the Serious Fraud Office said the charges were in connection with Polly Peck International PLC. Two other men who were arrested earlier Sunday had been interviewed and released without being charged, Staff said. Their names were not disclosed. Scotland Yard's fraud squad has been investigating alleged irregularities in dealings in Polly Peck's stock. The fruit and electronics giant was put in the hands of court-appointed administrators in October after its shares collapsed on the stock market. They are trying to deal with the company's 1.3 billion pound, or $2.5 billion, debt. Nadir has personal debts estimated at 40 million pounds, or $76 million.
